description: From Middle English now, nou, nu, from Old English nū, from Proto-West Germanic *nū, from Proto-Germanic *nu, from Proto-Indo-European *nū (“now”).

entries.meaning: (informal) Fashionable; popular; up to date; current.
examples: I think this band's sound is very now.

entries.meaning: (archaic, law) At the time the will is written. Used in order to prevent any inheritance from being transferred to a person of a future marriage. Does not indicate the existence of a previous marriage.
examples: Now wife.
Now I am six.
Stop that now, Jimmy!

entries.meaning: (sentential) Used to introduce a point, a qualification of what has previously been said, a remonstration or a rebuke.
examples: Now, we all want what is best for our children.
Now Jimmy, stop that.

entries.meaning: Differently from the immediate past; differently from a more remote past or a possible future; differently from all other times.
examples: Now I am ready.
We all now want the latest toys for our children.
We all want what is now best for our children.

entries.meaning: At the time reached within a narration.
examples: Now he remembered why he had come.
He now asked her whether she had made pudding.
The pudding was now ready to be served.

entries.meaning: Used to indicate a context of urgency.
examples: Now listen, we must do something about this.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) As 'but now': Very recently; not long ago; up to the present.
examples: They that but now, for honour and for plate, / Made the sea blush with blood, resign their hate.

entries.meaning: Used to address a switching side, or sharp change in attitude from before. (In this usage, now is usually emphasized).
examples: Now, you want to protect me. An hour ago, you were mercilessly bullying me!
His face fit his roles: now smiling, now earnest, now glowering, now raging.
Now is the right time.
There is no better time than now.

entries.meaning: (often with "the") The state of not paying attention to the future or the past.
examples: Synonyms: here and now; see also Thesaurus:the present
She is living in the now.

entries.meaning: (countable, chiefly in phenomenology) A particular instant in time, as perceived at that instant.

examples: I don't now. (intended: I don't know.)
